original_content:
In a world of 32-bit and 64-bit processors, it might surprise you to learn that Intel is releasing a 12-bit chip. Oh, wait, we mean 12-qubit. That makes more sense. Code named Tunnel Falls, the chip uses tiny silicon spin quantum bits, which Intel says are more advantageous than other schemes for encoding qubits. Theres a video about the device below.
It is a research chip and will be available to universities that might not be able to produce their own hardware. You probably arent going to find them listed on your favorite online reseller. Besides, the chip isnt going to be usable on a breadboard. It is still going to take a lot of support to get it running.
Intel claims the silicon qubit technology is a million times smaller than other qubit types. The size is on the order of a device transistor  50 nanometers square  simplifying things and allowing denser devices. In silicon spin qubits, information resides in the up or down spin of a single electron.
Of course, even Intel isnt suggesting that 12 qubits are enough for a game-changing quantum computer, but you do have to start somewhere. This chip may enable more researchers to test the technology and will undoubtedly help Intel accelerate its research to the next step.
There is a lot of talk that silicon is the way to go for scalable quantum computing. It makes you wonder if theres anything silicon cant do? You can access todays limited quantum computers in the proverbial cloud.
title: インテルが12-qubitチップを開発！
body: インテルが12キュービットチップ『Tunnel Falls』を開発し、高密度デバイスを実現した。シリコンスピン量子ビット技術を使用するこのチップは、専門家によって利用できるように実験的なものであり、数百万倍も小さいとされる。しかし、このチップは十分なサポートが必要であり、これが将来の量子コンピュータ研究に役立つことは間違いない。
titles: インテルが12-qubitチップを開発！
量子ビットのエンコードに優れる双子量子ビットを利用
研究用チップのため、一般市場には出荷されない
シリコン双子量子ビットは非常に小さいため、より密度の高いデバイスが使用できる
12-qubitは量子コンピュータにとってゲームチェンジャーではないが、研究を加速するための一歩
